definition[0]: the entrance to a room or building, or the area of floor or ground at the entrance
example[0]: She opened the door and stepped across the threshold.
definition[1]: the level at which something starts to happen or have an effect
note[0]: a high/low pain/boredom etc threshold (=the ability or inability to suffer a lot of pain or boredom before you react to it)
example[1]: Eighty percent of the vote was the threshold for approval of the plan.
definition[2]: at the beginning of a new and important event or development
example[2]: The creature is on the threshold of extinction.
note[1]: be on the threshold of something
heading[0]: – Meaning 2: the level at which something starts to happen or have an effect
example[3]: ‘Will it hurt?’ ‘That all depends on your pain threshold.’
example[4]: She loves challenges and admits she has a low boredom threshold.
example[5]: The Conservatives promised to help the lower paid by increasing the tax threshold.
example[6]: Professional football players have a pretty high pain threshold.
example[7]: I know that young children have very low boredom threshold.
example[8]: The value of many family homes far exceeds the inheritance tax threshold.
example[9]: the demand to lower the retirement threshold to 60
example[10]: They should raise the threshold to at least £245 a week.
example[11]: Such a person has sufficiently crossed the threshold of criminality to justify punishment.
definition[3]: the level at which something belongs in a particular class or is affected by a particular rule
example[12]: Many large mortgages were taken out, on the assumption that interest rates would remain below the ten percent threshold.
example[13]: The vehicles will have 70% U.S. content, which is the legal threshold for being an American car.
